Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: ABI development: A toolbox for analysis of long-term ecological dynamics using the Kepler Workflow System
Award.AbstractNarration: The University of Wisconsin Madison, The University of New Mexico, and the University of California Santa Barbara are awarded grants to develop a toolbox for automating the process of analyzing community change. Long-term data sets will be used to demonstrate data and system accessibility and functionality, and through implementation of new metrics we will gain insights into what drives change in ecological communities on a continental scale. Data will be accessed via the DataONE portal and the LTER Network Information System using the Ecological Metadata Language, and analyzed with R statistical routines within the Kepler Scientific Workflow Environment. The species makeup of ecological communities varies over time in response to changes in the environment. Analysis of this variability has a long history in ecology, yet because of the lack of long term data, ecological change in different localities has been studied in a so-called ?place for time? approach. That is, environmental conditions in one locality are considered to be comparable to the future conditions in another place. Although, this approach allows some insight into general trends it does not provide much information about rates and patterns of change. NSF programs like LTER and LTREB have generated long term observations of different ecological communities to allow for more realistic measures of how ecological communities change over time. This record will grow as automated observing platforms like NEON and GLEON contribute significantly to the long-term record. Along with the increasing availability of long-term datasets in on-line repositories, new methods for community change analysis are being developed. This open access toolbox will make community analysis more accessible and in turn expose a variety of indices to wider use, thorough testing, and improvement for measuring and visualizing ecological dynamics. Existing workflows will help reduce effort in data preparation and foster unprecedented potential for collaboration. Value added data products of community change indices across habitats are particularly valuable for education and outreach, and in broader synthetic activities related to environmental health, management, and dynamics at larger scales. Through the LTER Schoolyard program these data and understanding of environmental change will reach a large number and diversity of schoolchildren. For further information about the project and its software products, visit http://lter.limnology.wisc.edu/research/community-analysis-toolbox.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goals of this collaborative research project were to (1) gather a number of newly developed long-term ecological community change metrics into one easily accessible analytical toolbox, (2) develop automated workflows for preparing highly variable raw data into an appropriate standardized format for analysis, (3) make these workflows publicly available via the DataONE network of data repositories, (4) develop value added data products of community change metrics for various biotic communities and make them available to other researchers, (5) apply these metrics to long-term community data sets, and (6) design mechanisms for advanced workflow publishing and exchange. The UCSB component was primarily responsible for goals 1, 3 and 6, along with support for all 6 project goals. To do so, we created the "codyn" open access software package in the R programming language that included new metrics for understanding temporal and spatial dynamics of ecological communities. We also developed software tools that enable community ecology researchers to document and publish their computations to improve the openness and transparency of their research, thereby allowing other researchers to understand and build upon their work.  Also, to promote open science we published the ecological data sets that we compiled and all of our analytical code through the Environmental Data Initiative hosted at the University of Wisconsin, and through the DataONE federation of data repositories. We applied these tools and our new metrics (and other metrics) to several long-term data sets to assess how ecological communities change over time. This is particularly important because on-going and chronic changes in environmental conditions can alter ecological communities and potentially push them across tipping points. We found, in general, that a lot of communities are undergoing “re-ordering,” that is, much of the documented change over one to two decades reflects changes in abundance of species already present rather than losses of some species or gains in others. This clearly has conservation value because it might be possible to design strategies to mitigate undesirable change among species of concern.
